channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Hope rises that a vaccine can shield people with HIV from a deadly threat
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03220-1

Tests on monkeys with a simian version of the virus show that the BCG vaccine provides protection against the bacterium that causes TB.
item.dc:title: Hope rises that a vaccine can shield people with HIV from a deadly threat

item.title: Carl Sagan’s audacious search for Earth has lessons for science today
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03240-x

The test 30 years ago of what remote sensing could tell us about our own planet shows the value of looking with unbiased eyes at what we think we already know.
item.dc:title: Carl Sagan’s audacious search for Earth has lessons for science today

item.title: Long COVID research risks losing momentum – we need a moonshot
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03225-w

Investing US$1 billion every year for the next ten years into long COVID research could improve the lives of millions and save trillions in economic costs.
item.dc:title: Long COVID research risks losing momentum – we need a moonshot
item.dc:creator: Lisa McCorkell
Michael J. Peluso

item.title: A mystery source of pollution fouling the Great Barrier Reef is found at last
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03221-0

Nutrient-laced groundwater seeping up through the sea bed adds to an excess of nitrogen and phosphorus threatening the ecosystem.
item.dc:title: A mystery source of pollution fouling the Great Barrier Reef is found at last

item.title: Making conventional farming more biodiversity friendly
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03233-w

Making conventional farming more biodiversity friendly
item.dc:title: Making conventional farming more biodiversity friendly
item.dc:creator: Tobias Kuemmerle
Patrick Meyfroidt
Florence Pendrill

item.title: The EU must stick to its animal-welfare commitments
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03231-y

The EU must stick to its animal-welfare commitments
item.dc:title: The EU must stick to its animal-welfare commitments
item.dc:creator: Eugénie Duval
Benjamin Lecorps

item.title: Agriculture: reform the global food system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03232-x

Agriculture: reform the global food system
item.dc:title: Agriculture: reform the global food system
item.dc:creator: Joern Fischer
Elena Bennett
Guy Pe’er

item.title: From the archive: animal behaviour, and Darwin discusses organ loss
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03157-5

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: animal behaviour, and Darwin discusses organ loss

item.title: Smell loss from COVID fades quickly with help of new pill
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03244-7

The antiviral drug ensitrelvir eases both smell and taste loss, and is one of the few COVID-19 drugs available to people not at high risk of grave illness.
item.dc:title: Smell loss from COVID fades quickly with help of new pill
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: AI rapidly diagnoses brain tumours during surgery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03072-9

A machine-learning method to assess DNA can accurately classify brain tumours in real time. This rapid analysis might help surgeons to identify the tumour type when operating and to adjust their surgical strategy accordingly.
item.dc:title: AI rapidly diagnoses brain tumours during surgery
item.dc:creator: Lissa C. Baird

item.title: Science is under threat in Argentina — we must call out the danger
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03228-7

Extreme-right presidential front runner Javier Milei plans to disband ministries and privatize research. That would be disastrous for Argentina’s science and for the nation.
item.dc:title: Science is under threat in Argentina — we must call out the danger
item.dc:creator: Victor A. Ramos

item.title: Stem cells used to model a two-week-old human embryo
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03150-y

Researchers have used stem cells to create models that resemble human embryos at two weeks old, but bypass the earliest developmental stages — paving the way for studies that are not possible in human embryos.
item.dc:title: Stem cells used to model a two-week-old human embryo
item.dc:creator: Naomi Moris

item.title: Apple revival: how science is bringing historic varieties back to life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03229-6

Exploring the genomes of half-forgotten and heirloom apple varieties could help to ensure the future of the incomparable fruits.
item.dc:title: Apple revival: how science is bringing historic varieties back to life
item.dc:creator: Christopher Kemp

item.title: How to share data — not just equally, but equitably
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03239-4

Just as with many natural resources, wealthy countries have been extracting scientific data from poorer nations for centuries. Researchers are changing that.
item.dc:title: How to share data — not just equally, but equitably

item.title: Daily briefing: ‘Milkshake brain’ — why we gravitate towards fatty foods
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03260-7

A brain area helps to guide our eating behaviour by responding to the smooth texture of milkshakes and other rich options. Plus, first evidence that Neanderthals hunted cave lions and Carl Sagan’s groundbreaking plan to search for life on Earth.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: ‘Milkshake brain’ — why we gravitate towards fatty foods
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Author Correction: Outflows from the youngest stars are mostly molecular
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06744-8

Author Correction: Outflows from the youngest stars are mostly molecular
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Outflows from the youngest stars are mostly molecular

item.title: Targeting myeloid chemotaxis to reverse prostate cancer therapy resistance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06696-z

Targeting myeloid chemotaxis to reverse prostate cancer therapy resistance
item.dc:title: Targeting myeloid chemotaxis to reverse prostate cancer therapy resistance

item.title: Milkshake neuroscience: how the brain nudges us toward fatty foods
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03243-8

Brain imaging shows how high-fat foods exert their powerful pull.
item.dc:title: Milkshake neuroscience: how the brain nudges us toward fatty foods
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Every day, I release balloons into the Antarctic sky
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03237-6

Electronic engineer Axel Bres predicts the weather from one of the world’s most isolated islands.
item.dc:title: Every day, I release balloons into the Antarctic sky
item.dc:creator: Patricia Maia Noronha

item.title: How would we know whether there is life on Earth? This bold experiment found out
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03230-z

Thirty years ago, astronomer Carl Sagan convinced NASA to turn a passing space probe’s instruments on Earth to look for life — with results that still reverberate today.
item.dc:title: How would we know whether there is life on Earth? This bold experiment found out
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: How ChatGPT is transforming the postdoc experience
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03235-8

Around one in three respondents to Nature’s global postdoc survey are using AI chatbots to help to refine text, generate or edit code, wrangle the literature in their field and more.
item.dc:title: How ChatGPT is transforming the postdoc experience
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: Daily briefing: ChatGPT use makes a mockery of grant applications
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03254-5

What’s the point of asking scientists to write documents that can be easily created with AI? Plus, the Psyche mission begins its journey to the largest metallic object in the Solar System and what we know about the side effects of Ozempic and similar anti-obesity drugs.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: ChatGPT use makes a mockery of grant applications
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Anti-ageing molecule boosts fertility in ageing mice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03224-x

‘Undeniably groundbreaking’ work shows that declining egg quality in older mice can be reversed with a dietary supplement.
item.dc:title: Anti-ageing molecule boosts fertility in ageing mice
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Argentina election: front runner vows to slash science funding
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03191-3

If elected president, economist Javier Milei has pledged to eliminate government spending on research and shut down the environment and health ministries.
item.dc:title: Argentina election: front runner vows to slash science funding
item.dc:creator: Martín De Ambrosio
Fermín Koop

item.title: Soft-landing methods aim to simplify structural biology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03236-7

Linking mass spectroscopy with cryo-electron microscopy could transform understanding of complex protein structures — if scientists can show that samples remain intact when they hit their target.
item.dc:title: Soft-landing methods aim to simplify structural biology
item.dc:creator: Michael Eisenstein

item.title: Methods section too short? Use online protocols to make complex techniques understandable
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03249-2

New wet-lab methods can be hard to share owing to their complexity, but with a little extra effort, you can give users a leg-up in getting started.
item.dc:title: Methods section too short? Use online protocols to make complex techniques understandable
item.dc:creator: Lars Borm

item.title: Snowbanks are set to get whiter — offsetting climate change’s effects
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03106-2

Projected decreases in soot deposition mean that Northern Hemisphere snow will be more reflective and thus less prone to melting before 2100.
item.dc:title: Snowbanks are set to get whiter — offsetting climate change’s effects

item.title: Author Correction: Child wasting and concurrent stunting in low- and middle-income countries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06695-0

Author Correction: Child wasting and concurrent stunting in low- and middle-income countries
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Child wasting and concurrent stunting in low- and middle-income countries

Author Correction: Early-childhood linear growth faltering in low- and middle-income countries
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Early-childhood linear growth faltering in low- and middle-income countries

item.title: The first digital pandemic, and the dangers of economic nationalism: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03217-w

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: The first digital pandemic, and the dangers of economic nationalism: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Runes on Viking stones speak to an ancient queen’s power
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03107-1

Analysis of carved inscriptions more than 1,000 years old suggests the prominence of the Viking queen Thyra.
item.dc:title: Runes on Viking stones speak to an ancient queen’s power

item.title: Placenta forms with aid of mother’s microbiome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03105-3

The organ that nourishes the developing embryo does not develop properly in mice that lack the usual gut microbes.
item.dc:title: Placenta forms with aid of mother’s microbiome

item.title: Australia’s feral horses need ‘urgent’ control: scientists welcome latest report
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03030-5

Ecologists have praised government recommendations, but some say more concrete action — including a cull — is needed.
item.dc:title: Australia’s feral horses need ‘urgent’ control: scientists welcome latest report
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Could new ‘narrative’ CVs transform research culture?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03219-8

Funders are turning to a format that probes societal impact and acknowledges contributions from non-academic colleagues.
item.dc:title: Could new ‘narrative’ CVs transform research culture?
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: ChatGPT use shows that the grant-application system is broken
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03238-5

The fact that artificial intelligence can do much of the work makes a mockery of the process. It’s time to make it easier for scientists to ask for research funding.
item.dc:title: ChatGPT use shows that the grant-application system is broken
item.dc:creator: Juan Manuel Parrilla

item.title: NASA’s Psyche mission is on its way to this huge metal asteroid
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03165-5

The space rock — possibly the exposed core of a planet that didn’t finish forming — could reveal details about the Solar System’s origins.
item.dc:title: NASA’s Psyche mission is on its way to this huge metal asteroid
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Astronomy society revises harassment policy after outcry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03208-x

The International Astronomical Union clarified changes to its code of conduct after researchers voiced concern that it protected harassers.
item.dc:title: Astronomy society revises harassment policy after outcry
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wild

item.title: I advocate an African research agenda for African development
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03241-w

As Uganda’s science minister, Monica Musenero pushes to connect scientific research to economic development in her country and her continent.
item.dc:title: I advocate an African research agenda for African development
item.dc:creator: Christopher Bendana

item.title: Daily briefing: Words detected inside ancient Roman scrolls sealed by Mount Vesuvius eruption
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03246-5

A student has cracked a method for reading charred, unopenable scrolls from the ancient Roman city of Herculaneum. Plus, how to build Moon roads using focused beams of sunlight, and the largest-ever atlas of the human brain.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Words detected inside ancient Roman scrolls sealed by Mount Vesuvius eruption
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Anti-obesity drugs’ side effects: what we know so far
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03183-3

Recent studies evaluate risks associated with drugs such as Wegovy and Mounjaro.
item.dc:title: Anti-obesity drugs’ side effects: what we know so far
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: How to build Moon roads using focused beams of sunlight
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03207-y

Experiments with lasers reveal a way to melt lunar dust into solid paving slabs.
item.dc:title: How to build Moon roads using focused beams of sunlight
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Bamboo gains super strength thanks to an ingredient from within
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03108-0

A component of bamboo itself can be used to bind the plant’s cells to form a strong material — no petrochemical glue needed.
item.dc:title: Bamboo gains super strength thanks to an ingredient from within

item.title: Mental health: The invisible effects of neglected tropical diseases
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02973-z

The psychological burden of disability and stigma has been overlooked, to the detriment of those affected and their carers.
item.dc:title: Mental health: The invisible effects of neglected tropical diseases
item.dc:creator: Simon Makin

item.title: Reproducibility trial: 246 biologists get different results from same data sets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03177-1

Wide distribution of findings shows how analytical choices drive conclusions.
item.dc:title: Reproducibility trial: 246 biologists get different results from same data sets
item.dc:creator: Anil Oza

item.title: AI reads text from ancient Herculaneum scroll for the first time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03212-1

Machine-learning technique reveals Greek words in CT scans of rolled-up papyrus.
item.dc:title: AI reads text from ancient Herculaneum scroll for the first time
item.dc:creator: Jo Marchant

item.title: Daily briefing: Why obesity researchers want to move beyond BMI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03227-8

A growing movement is pushing to go beyond body mass index as a diagnostic test for obesity. Plus, samples from asteroid Bennu are rich in the building blocks of life and how artificial intelligence is helping us understand dangerous viruses.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Why obesity researchers want to move beyond BMI
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: This is the largest map of the human brain ever made
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03192-2

Researchers catalogue more than 3,000 different types of cell in our most complex organ.
item.dc:title: This is the largest map of the human brain ever made
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Clostridioides difficile infection drives neuronal inflammation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02640-3

Infection by the bacterium Clostridioides difficile can be fatal in a clinical setting. Insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying such infection might offer targets for the search to develop new treatments.
item.dc:title: Clostridioides difficile infection drives neuronal inflammation
item.dc:creator: Klaus Aktories

item.title: Climate and conservation science persevere in the face of major challenges
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03087-2

But research will need to renew and redouble efforts to provide solutions as the climate emergency deepens.
item.dc:title: Climate and conservation science persevere in the face of major challenges
item.dc:creator: Simon Baker

item.title: Where is the strongest research focus on the environment?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02869-y

The alignment of high-quality research to Sustainable Development Goals on climate and conservation varies widely between the world’s regions.
item.dc:title: Where is the strongest research focus on the environment?
item.dc:creator: Simon Baker
Bec Crew

item.title: Arenium-ion-catalysed halodealkylation of fully alkylated silanes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06646-9

A new method is described that uses arenium-ion-catalysed halodealkylation of silanes with four alkyl groups, typically considered synthetic dead ends, to convert Me4Si and related quaternary silanes into orthogonally substituted (functionalized) silanes.
item.dc:title: Arenium-ion-catalysed halodealkylation of fully alkylated silanes
item.dc:creator: Tao He
Hendrik F. T. Klare
Martin Oestreich

item.title: Genotyping, sequencing and analysis of 140,000 adults from Mexico City
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06595-3

Genotype and exome sequencing of 150,000 participants and whole-genome sequencing of 9,950 selected individuals recruited into the Mexico City Prospective Study constitute a valuable, publicly available resource of non-European sequencing data.
item.dc:title: Genotyping, sequencing and analysis of 140,000 adults from Mexico City
item.dc:creator: Andrey Ziyatdinov
Jason Torres
Jesús Alegre-Díaz
Joshua Backman
Joelle Mbatchou
Michael Turner

item.title: Unraveling the functional dark matter through global metagenomics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06583-7

A computational approach to generate reference-free protein families from the sequence space in metagenomes reveals an enormously diverse functional space.
item.dc:title: Unraveling the functional dark matter through global metagenomics

item.title: Precipitation regime changes in High Mountain Asia driven by cleaner air
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06619-y

Dipolar precipitation change in High Mountain Asia during summer is primarily driven by weakened westerly jet and decadal variations in the South Asian monsoon, and the dipolar pattern is projected to shift to a monopolar wetting trend in the 2040s.
item.dc:title: Precipitation regime changes in High Mountain Asia driven by cleaner air
item.dc:creator: Jie Jiang
Tianjun Zhou
Yun Qian
Chao Li
Fengfei Song
Hongmei Li
Xiaolong Chen
Wenxia Zhang
Ziming Chen

item.title: Apoptotic stress causes mtDNA release during senescence and drives the SASP
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06621-4

During senescence, minority mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization leads to the release of mtDNA into the cytosol through BAX and BAK macropores, in turn activating the cGAS–STING pathway, a major regulator of the senescence-associated secretory phenotype.
item.dc:title: Apoptotic stress causes mtDNA release during senescence and drives the SASP
item.dc:creator: Stella Victorelli
Hanna Salmonowicz

Helene Martini

item.title: Mexican Biobank advances population and medical genomics of diverse ancestries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06560-0

Nationwide genomic biobank in Mexico unravels demographic history and complex trait architecture from 6,057 individuals.
item.dc:title: Mexican Biobank advances population and medical genomics of diverse ancestries
item.dc:creator: Mashaal Sohail
María J. Palma-Martínez
Amanda Y. Chong
Consuelo D. Quinto-Cortés

item.title: State estimation of a physical system with unknown governing equations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06574-8

A parametrization strategy for stochastic variational inference with Markov Gaussian processes is presented for state estimation of a physical system whose underlying dynamical equations are partially or completely unknown.
item.dc:title: State estimation of a physical system with unknown governing equations
item.dc:creator: Kevin Course
Prasanth B. Nair

item.title: Learning from prepandemic data to forecast viral escape
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06617-0

EVEscape, a flexible framework using deep learning and biophysical structural information, enables early identification of concerning mutations in viruses with pandemic potential, facilitating the development of vaccines and therapeutics.
item.dc:title: Learning from prepandemic data to forecast viral escape
item.dc:creator: Nicole N. Thadani
Sarah Gurev
Pascal Notin
Noor Youssef
Nathan J. Rollins
Daniel Ritter
Chris Sander
Yarin Gal
Debora S. Marks

item.title: High-fidelity gates and mid-circuit erasure conversion in an atomic qubit
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06438-1

This study reports gates between qubits encoded in the nuclear spin state of Yb atoms trapped in optical tweezers, reaching very high fidelity and demonstrating mid-circuit conversion of errors into erasure errors.
item.dc:title: High-fidelity gates and mid-circuit erasure conversion in an atomic qubit
item.dc:creator: Shuo Ma
Genyue Liu
Pai Peng
Bichen Zhang
Sven Jandura
Jahan Claes
Alex P. Burgers
Guido Pupillo
Shruti Puri
Jeff D. Thompson

item.title: Ultra-fast deep-learned CNS tumour classification during surgery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06615-2

Sturgeon is a pretrained neural network that uses incremental results from nanopore sequencing to rapidly classify central nervous system tumours and can be used to aid critical decision-making during surgery.
item.dc:title: Ultra-fast deep-learned CNS tumour classification during surgery
item.dc:creator: C. Vermeulen
M. Pagès-Gallego
L. Kester
M. E. G. Kranendonk
P. Wesseling
N. Verburg
P. de Witt Hamer
E. J. Kooi
L. Dankmeijer
J. van der Lugt
K. van Baarsen
E. W. Hoving
B. B. J. Tops
J. de Ridder

item.title: Erasure conversion in a high-fidelity Rydberg quantum simulator
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06516-4

Erasure conversion and detection are used in a Rydberg quantum simulator to create Bell states with high fidelity, competitive with other state-of-the-art platforms.
item.dc:title: Erasure conversion in a high-fidelity Rydberg quantum simulator
item.dc:creator: Pascal Scholl
Adam L. Shaw
Richard Bing-Shiun Tsai
Ran Finkelstein
Joonhee Choi
Manuel Endres

item.title: Structures illustrate step-by-step mitochondrial transcription initiation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06643-y

A cryogenic electron microscopy study presents structures characterizing the initiation of RNA synthesis by yeast mitochondrial RNA polymerase at single-nucleotide addition steps.
item.dc:title: Structures illustrate step-by-step mitochondrial transcription initiation
item.dc:creator: Quinten Goovaerts
Jiayu Shen
Brent De Wijngaert
Urmimala Basu
Smita S. Patel
Kalyan Das

item.title: Doping of molecular semiconductors through proton-coupled electron transfer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06504-8

Proton-coupled electron-transfer reactions are used to achieve efficient chemical doping of organic semiconductor thin films under ambient conditions, and a reference-electrode-free, resistive pH sensor based on the method is proposed.
item.dc:title: Doping of molecular semiconductors through proton-coupled electron transfer
item.dc:creator: Masaki Ishii
Yu Yamashita
Shun Watanabe
Katsuhiko Ariga
Jun Takeya

item.title: Design and testing of a humanized porcine donor for xenotransplantation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06594-4

Using kidneys from a genetically engineered porcine donor transplanted into a cynomolgus monkey model, the design, creation and long-term function of kidney grafts supporting life are explored.
item.dc:title: Design and testing of a humanized porcine donor for xenotransplantation

item.title: Flexible circuit mechanisms for context-dependent song sequencing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06632-1

Insights into the underlying neuronal circuitry of the Drosophila song production system are provided using song patterning of males near versus far from the female.
item.dc:title: Flexible circuit mechanisms for context-dependent song sequencing
item.dc:creator: Frederic A. Roemschied
Diego A. Pacheco
Max J. Aragon
Elise C. Ireland
Xinping Li
Kyle Thieringer
Rich Pang
Mala Murthy

item.title: High-fidelity parallel entangling gates on a neutral-atom quantum computer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06481-y

The realization of two-qubit entangling gates with 99.5% fidelity on up to 60 rubidium atoms in parallel is reported, surpassing the surface-code threshold for error correction and laying the groundwork for neutral-atom quantum computers.
item.dc:title: High-fidelity parallel entangling gates on a neutral-atom quantum computer
item.dc:creator: Simon J. Evered
Dolev Bluvstein
Marcin Kalinowski
Sepehr Ebadi
Tom Manovitz
Hengyun Zhou

Nishad Maskara
Harry Levine
Giulia Semeghini
Markus Greiner

Mikhail D. Lukin

item.title: A planetary collision afterglow and transit of the resultant debris cloud
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06573-9

Infrared brightening and luminosity observations from a young, solar-like star suggest a collision between two exoplanets producing a hot, highly extended post-impact remnant and transit of the debris causing the visible light eclipse of the host star.
item.dc:title: A planetary collision afterglow and transit of the resultant debris cloud
item.dc:creator: Matthew Kenworthy
Simon Lock

item.title: A guide to the Nature Index
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03091-6

A description of the terminology and methodology used in this supplement, and a guide to the functionality that is available free online at natureindex.com.
item.dc:title: A guide to the Nature Index

item.title: Why BMI is flawed — and how to redefine obesity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03143-x

The main diagnostic test for obesity — the body mass index — accounts for only height and weight, leaving out a slew of factors that influence body fat and health.
item.dc:title: Why BMI is flawed — and how to redefine obesity
item.dc:creator: McKenzie Prillaman

item.title: ‘Abortion tests’ developed in Poland spark concern
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03129-9

Scientists are questioning the reliability and ethics of tests to detect abortion drugs in biological samples.
item.dc:title: ‘Abortion tests’ developed in Poland spark concern
item.dc:creator: Layal Liverpool

item.title: Taking time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03167-3

The write stuff.
item.dc:title: Taking time
item.dc:creator: John Gilbey

item.title: The technique that can find a system’s state through data alone
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03070-x

Pinpointing the state of a complex system is tricky, especially when the underlying mathematical equations aren’t known. But a data-driven technique makes light work of it — and could even change the way that models are formulated.
item.dc:title: The technique that can find a system’s state through data alone
item.dc:creator: Brendan Keith

item.title: Facing racism in science, ‘I decided to prove them wrong’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03205-0

Immunologist Dequina Nicholas shares why mentorship is crucial for first-generation scientists.
item.dc:title: Facing racism in science, ‘I decided to prove them wrong’
item.dc:creator: Lesley Evans Ogden

item.title: Violent collision rocks a young planetary system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03069-4

When two worlds collide, they leave more than the shambles of dusty ejecta. Astronomers have detected light from a post-collision remnant, providing the best evidence so far for planetary-scale collisions in exoplanetary systems.
item.dc:title: Violent collision rocks a young planetary system
item.dc:creator: Carl Melis

item.title: Polar researchers strive for progress despite adverse world events
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03088-1

The pandemic and the invasion of Ukraine have had a significant impact on international collaboration and field access.
item.dc:title: Polar researchers strive for progress despite adverse world events
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer
